What are the options available for configuring the Verus Daemon, and how can they be specified?

The Verus Daemon is a crucial component of the Verus ecosystem, and it can be configured using various options to customize its behavior. These options can be specified either through command-line arguments or by storing them in a configuration file called `VRSC.conf`. 

**Command-Line Options:**
When running the Verus Daemon from the command line, you can specify options using the format `verusd [options]`. For example, you can use the `-?` option to display this help message. Other options include `-alerts` to receive and display P2P network alerts, `-alertnotify=<cmd>` to execute a command when a relevant alert is received, and `-blocknotify=<cmd>` to execute a command when the best block changes.

**Configuration File (VRSC.conf):**
Instead of specifying options through the command line, you can store them in a configuration file called `VRSC.conf`. This file is loaded when the Verus Daemon starts up and provides the standard configuration. Options specified in the `VRSC.conf` file will be overridden by any conflicting settings provided through the command line. To use options from the `VRSC.conf` file, omit the leading `-` character.

**Example VRSC.conf File:**
Here is an example of what a `VRSC.conf` file might look like:
```
rpcuser=user
rpcpassword=pass
rpcport=27486
server=1
txindex=1
rpcallowip=127.0.0.1
rpchost=127.0.0.1
addnode=195.253.48.236:27485
```
**Standard Locations:**
The `Verus Wallet.dat`, `Chaindata`, and `VRSC.conf` files have standard locations on different operating systems. On Linux, these files are located at `~/.komodo/VRSC`, while on Mac OS, they are located at `~/Library/Application Support/Komodo/VRSC`. On Windows 10, they are located at `%AppData%\Roaming\Komodo\VRSC\`.

**Other Options:**
There are many other options available for configuring the Verus Daemon. For example, you can use the `-bootstrap` option to remove previous chain data and download and extract the bootstrap archive. You can use the `-checkblocks=<n>` option to specify how many blocks to check at startup, and the `-checklevel=<n>` option to specify how thorough the block verification of `-checkblocks` is. You can also use the `-conf=<file>` option to specify a configuration file, and the `-daemon` option to run the Verus Daemon in the background as a daemon and accept commands.
